Award.AwardTitle: IRES: US-China Collaboration on Bio-Inspired Aerodynamic Designs for the Development of Next Generation Micro Air Vehicles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research theme of this IRES program is the design and testing of microscale air vehicles (MAVs) based on mimicking the flight mechanisms of birds, insects, and bats. Six graduate and six undergraduate students will go to China to conduct research projects at the J.C. Wu Research Center in Aerodynamics at Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU). The students, with their Chinese mentors, will explore novel airfoil and wing designs that could improve aerodynamic performance of MAVs as well as the flight agility and versatility that are needed for advanced applications. The program will also provide cultural training to the students to broaden their understanding of the Chinese environment and global cooperation.

This project engages the students in a cutting-edge research area, involving the understanding and mechanical replication of flight by living creatures. The research involves both experimental testing with sophisticated instrumentation as well as detailed mathematical modeling of both structural mechanics and fluid dynamics. This international experience will broaden the students? understanding of the world, especially China, and prepare them to engage with Chinese and American colleagues in the future course of their careers. The development of reliable and efficient MAVs can have technological, environmental and political impact through various remote sensing, monitoring and actuation applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome report

This International Research Experiences for Students (IRES) project has provided exciting international research experiences for American undergraduate and/or graduate students to carry out international collaborative research at the J.C. Wu Research Center of Aerodynamics of Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) in Shanghai, China for at least 8 weeks. The objective of this IRES project is to provide the future American engineers and early-career researchers a global perspective and opportunities for their professional growth through meaningful international cooperative research training, networking and mentoring in the field of aerospace engineering in general and applied aerodynamics in particular.  

The research focus of this IRES program is bio-inspired aerodynamic designs for the development of next generation micro-air-vehicles (MAVs). Comprehensive studies have been performed by the IRES students to leverage the aerodynamic configurations and flight features found in natural flyers such as insects, birds and bats, and appropriately apply them to the designs of next generation Micro-Air-Vehicles (MAV) for improved aerodynamic performance. In addition to working in the laboratory to conduct the international collaborative research, the IRES students have also participated various social and cultural exchanging activities, such as orientation social, lunchtime seminars/meetings, Chinese language and culture training, and field trips to visit industrial and historical sites, to enhance student-faculty and student-student interactions to help the IRES students to build their personal friendship and connections with participating Chinese mentors, research staff members and students as well as among the IRES participants on which to build future collaborations.

The scientific findings derived from this IRES project would lead to novel airfoil and wing designs to significantly improve aerodynamic performance of MAVs as well as their flight agility and versatility that are critical to many industrial applications, not least among them America’s defense and national security concerns.  The 8-week’s visit of the IRES students to SJTU in Shanghai, China through this IRES program is expected to bring significant benefits to the future American engineers and early-career researchers. It would enhance their international education and research experiences by providing opportunities for personal network development on which to build future collaborations, training them to be capable of performing well in an international research environment in order to remain at the forefront of world science and technology, making them to be more proficient in the technical subjects, and letting them to be familiar with Chinese culture and tradition, applicable technological trends and business practices. This IRES program would also foster a stronger project-based collaboration between the Iowa State University (ISU) and SJTU.

This IRES project has fostered interdisciplinary interactions and brought together IRES participants, Chinese professors, graduate and undergraduate students with multi-cultural background in a multi-level learning experience infused with the excitement of discovery. Research results derived from this project has been presented at various conferences and published in scientific journals.
